Description: LINKED DATASET AND VIRTUAL RESEARCH DATA CENTER - THE PROPOSED WORK IS A JOINT EFFORT TO DEVELOP GENOMIC AND BIOINFORMATIC APPROACHES TO DISSECT MAIZE, MAIZE'S WILD RELATIVES, AND OTHER CROPS' AGRONOMIC TRAITS. THE GOAL IS TO IDENTIFY SPECIFIC NUCLEOTIDE VARIANTS THAT COULD BE USED IN CROP IMPROVEMENT WITH A SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON THOSE THAT ARE THE SOURCE OF GENETIC LOAD. 1. GENOMICALLY CHARACTERIZE GERMPLASM FOR RARE NUCLEOTIDE VARIANTS. 2. CHARACTERIZE GERMPLASM FOR HYBRID VIGOR, DEVELOPMENTAL TRAITS, AND COLD TOLERANCE. 3. DEVELOP STATISTICAL ANALYSIS APPROACHES FOR RELATING GENOTYPE AND PHENOTYPE AND TO IDENTIFY MUTATIONS CONTRIBUTING TO GENETIC LOAD. DEPLOY THESE ANALYSIS APPROACHES IN EASY TO USE SOFTWARE FOR THE ENTIRE COMMUNITY.
AGROCLIMATE - THIS PROJECT WILL VALIDATE A HUMANE METHOD OF PIG EUTHANIZATION.

SUPPLEMENTAL ESP 59-3AEU-0-0015 TO UMBRELLA AGREEMENT 58-3AEU-0-0014M - FOCUSED ON MAIZE, ONE OF THE MOST VALUABLE CROP SPECIES WORLDWIDE, THE GENOMES TO FIELDS (G2F) INITIATIVE FOCUSES ON LEVERAGING AND BUILDING ON THE PUBLICLY-FUNDED MAIZE GENOME SEQUENCING PROJECTS TO ADVANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLE OF EXISTENT GENETIC VARIATION TO INCREASE PLANTS' RESILIENCE TO ENVIRONMENTAL INFLUENCES. THE GENOTYPE BY ENVIRONMENT (GXE) PROJECT IS A MULTI-INVESTIGATOR PROJECT THAT IS PART OF G2F. SINCE 2014, THIS PROJECT HAS EVALUATED MORE THAN 1,500 UNIQUE MAIZE HYBRIDS ACROSS MORE THAN 77 ENVIRONMENTS FOR A TOTAL OF MORE THAN 45,000 EXPERIMENTAL PLOTS. THIS FUNDING WILL CONTRIBUTE TO CONTINUE THIS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT INTO THE FUTURE INCLUDING SUPPORT FOR SEED PRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION, DATA COLLECTION, HIGH-THROUGHPUT PHENOTYPING DEPLOYMENT, AND DATA ANALYSIS.

NDSU AGRICULTURAL STATISTICS PROGRAM - 1. DEVELOP CROPPING SYSTEMS WHICH IMPROVE SOIL HEALTH THROUGH INCLUSION OF PEAS OR LENTILS. 2. DETERMINE THE EFFECT OF CROP SEQUENCE AND ROTATION LENGTH ON NODULATION AND ROOT ROT IN PEAS AND LENTILS. 3. DETERMINE IF YIELD AND PROTEIN OF SMALL GRAIN CROPS CAN BE SUSTAINED FOLLOWING FIELD PEA OR LENTIL USING SOIL NITROGEN CREDITS IN A NO-TILL, SEMI-ARID CROPPING SYSTEM.

COLLECTION, ANALYSIS & PUBLICATION OF PRIMARY CROP & LIVESTOCK STATISTICS DATA - 1. DOCUMENT THE SURVIVAL AND LONGEVITY OF SPOTTED AND MEADOW KNAPWEED SEED IN THE SOIL SEED BANK, AND MONITOR THE POPULATION DEMOGRAPHY OF SPOTTED AND MEADOW KNAPWEED IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND HOW VARIOUS LIFE STAGES CONTRIBUTE TO POPULATION GROWTH. 2. DETERMINE THE EFFECT OF HABITAT AND BIOCONTROL AGENT DAMAGE ON PLANT PERFORMANCE AND FIELD DENSITIES OF BLACK AND PALE SWALLOW-WORT.

INTEGRATING DISPARATE DATA - BOVINE RESPIRATORY DISEASE (BRD) COMPLEX IS AN ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT COMPLEX OF DISEASES CAUSED BY TRANSPORT STRESS AND BACTERIAL AND VIRAL PATHOGENS INCLUDING MANNHEIMIA HAEMOLYTICA, PASTEURELLA MULTOCIDA, HISTOPHILUS SOMNI, AND MYCOPLASMA BOVIS. THE ABILITY TO RAPIDLY IDENTIFY SICK CATTLE BEFORE THE ONSET OF SEVERE DISEASE WOULD ENABLE THE TARGETED, LIMITED USE OF ANTIBIOTICS.

COLLECTION, ANALYSIS & PUBLICATION OF STATISTICS DATA - 1) DEVELOPMENT OF VALIDATED, QUANTIFIABLE ASSAYS FOR SPECIFIC DISEASES OF CONCERN TO EACH RAC; AND 2) IN-LAB HIGH-THROUGHPUT TESTING OF FIELD SAMPLES OF CROP RESIDUES AND/OR SOIL TO QUANTIFY PATHOGEN LOADS. THEN DURING THE GROWING SEASON, WE CAN TEST SEED AND PLANT TISSUE, AS WELL AS FIELD-SUPPLIED AIR SAMPLES TO DETECT AND QUANTIFY SPORES OF VARIOUS DISEASES, ASSUMING THE GENETIC MARKERS EXIST FOR THE SPORES IN QUESTION.

CENSUS OF AGRICULTURE LIST BUILDING AND PROMOTION PROJECT TO SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS - UTILIZE GENOMIC APPROACHES TO MAP RESISTANCE LOCI FOR KEY CUCURBIT DISEASES, BY DEVELOPMENT AND VERIFICATION OF MOLECULAR MARKERS FOR EFFICIENT TRAIT SELECTION AND GENE PYRAMIDING, AND INTROGRESSION OF DISEASE RESISTANCES INTO ADVANCED MELON BREEDING LINES.

CENSUS OF AGRICULTURE - DISSEMINATE DATA AND IMPROVE CENSUS COVERAGE FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS - THE OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP A SYSTEMATIC APPROACH FOR IDENTIFYING LOCI TO USE FOR METAGENOMIC STUDIES THAT WILL CHARACTERIZE DIFFERENT FORMAE SPECIALES OF FUSARIUM OXYSPORUM.

COLLECTION, ANALYSIS AND PUBLICATION OF PRIMARY CROP AND LIVESTOCK STATISTICAL DATA - 1) DEVELOPMENT OF VALIDATED, QUANTIFIABLE ASSAYS FOR SPECIFIC DISEASES OF CONCERN TO EACH RAC; AND 2) IN-LAB HIGH-THROUGHPUT TESTING OF FIELD SAMPLES OF CROP RESIDUES AND/OR SOIL TO QUANTIFY PATHOGEN LOADS. THEN DURING THE GROWING SEASON, WE CAN TEST SEED AND PLANT TISSUE, AS WELL AS FIELD-SUPPLIED AIR SAMPLES TO DETECT AND QUANTIFY SPORES OF VARIOUS DISEASES, ASSUMING THE GENETIC MARKERS EXIST FOR THE SPORES IN QUESTION.

CENSUS CAPTURE-RECAPTURE METHODOLOGY - PROJECT 1 - GENETICS & BREEDING OF FHB RESISTANT SOFT WHITE & RED WINTER WHEAT FOR NORTHEAST: 1) DEVELOP FHB RESISTANT SOFT WHEAT CULTIVARS FOR THE NORTHEASTERN U.S; 2) PYRAMID FHB RESISTANCE GENES BY HYBRIDIZING ELITE LINES WITH NATIVE FHB RESISTANCE TO NEW SOURCES OF FHB RESISTANCE BOTH ASIAN AND OTHER SOURCES; 3) EVALUATE FHB RESISTANT LINES IN NEW YORK REGIONAL TRIALS FOR RELEASE, FARMER RECOMMENDATIONS, AND SEED INCREASE; AND 4) PARTICIPATE IN THE COORDINATED SHARING OF INFORMATION FROM THE ABOVE ACTIVITIES TO GENERATE A COMPREHENSIVE SOURCE OF INFORMATION THAT CAN BE USED IN FORWARD BREEDING STRATEGIES. PROJECT 2 - MALE STERILE FACILITATED RECURRENT SELECTION FOR FHB RESISTANCE (MPI-5): THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADVANCE MALE-STERILE FACILITATED RECURRENT SELECTION POPULATIONS THAT HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED TO COMBINE GENES FOR FHB RESISTANCE FROM MULTIPLE SOURCES IN SOFT WINTER WHEAT BACKGROUNDS ADAPTED TO THE EASTERN U.S. PROJECT 3 - COORDINATED PHENOTYPING OF UNIFORM NURSERIES AND OFFICIAL VARIETY TRIALS: SCREEN AND EVALUATE APPROX. 450 UNIQUE ADVANCED BREEDING LINES AND RELEASED CULTIVARS FOR FHB RESISTANCE. PROJECT 4 - IMPLEMENTING GENOMIC SELECTION FOR FHB RESISTANCE IN SOFT WINTER WHEAT (SWW) ADAPTED TO THE CORN BELT: 1) TO IMPLEMENT GENOMIC SELECTION (GS) FOR FHB RESISTANCE IN SOFT WINTER WHEAT BY COMPLETING TWO CYCLES OF GS; AND 2) INITIATE EVALUATION OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF GS.
DEVELOP A PROGRAM TO QUALIFY STUDENTS TO BECOME AGRICULTURAL STATISTICIANS - ANALYZE CURRENTLY AVAILABLE TECHNOLOGIES FOR THE MOBILE PYROLYSIS AND FIELD APPLICATION OF JUNIPER BIOMASS.

USDA/NASS ONLINE GEOSPATIAL APPLICATIONS CROPSCAPE AND VEGSCAPE SYSTEMS MAINTAINING, HOSTING AND ENHANCEMENT OF NASS OPERATION - THIS PROPOSAL EXPANDS AND EXTENDS THE RESEARCH IN THE APPROVED 2013 HRI GRANT ON THE TESTING OF FUNGAL BIOCONTROL AGENTS AGAINST AMBROSIA BEETLES, WITH NEW EXPERIMENTS BASED ON NEW DATA OBTAINED FROM OUR STUDIES ON X. CRASSIUSCULUS. THIS EXTENSION ALSO ALLOWS A SECOND YEAR OF FIELD WORK ON TESTING THE EFFICACY OF THESE CONTROL AGENTS IN NEW YORK AND IN TENNESSEE. 1) DETERMINE FOUNDRESS SURVIVAL AND BROOD PRODUCTION FOLLOWING EXPOSURE TO BOLTS TREATED WITH MYCOINSECTICIDES. 2) EVALUATE THE INTERACTION BETWEEN T. HARZIANUM AND THE BEETLE-SYMBIOTIC FUNGI AND DETERMINE IMPACT ON BROOD PRODUCTION. 3) COMPARE EFFICACY OF SPRAYING TREES WITH B. BASSIANA, M. BRUNNEUM OR T. HARZIANUM FOR AMBROSIA BEETLE CONTROL.

DISSEMINATION AND PRESERVATION OF DIGITAL AGRIC. ECONOMIC DATA, STATISTICS & MARKET INFORMATION ACROSS SEVERAL STATISTICAL AGENCIES IN USDA. - RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM DYSFUNCTION ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED WILDFIRE ACTIVITY, INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, AND EXPANDING CONIFERS IS NEGATIVELY IMPACTING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND A VARIETY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ACROSS THE WESTERN UNITED STATES. THESE FACTORS HAVE SEVERE ECONOMIC IMPLICATIONS; FOR EXAMPLE, FEDERAL FIRE SUPPRESSION EXPENDITURES IN FY 2017 APPROACHED $3 BILLION. THE INCREASING FREQUENCY OF WILDFIRES ACROSS WESTERN RANGELANDS REMAINS A THREAT TO ECOSYSTEM STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION. IN GREAT BASIN RANGELANDS, WILDFIRE OFTEN CREATES A POSITIVE FEEDBACK BY INCREASING INVASIVE ANNUALS AND ALTERING FUEL LOADING. UNDERSTANDING THE DYNAMICS OF THE PLANT COMMUNITY-BOTH IN RESPONSE TO WILDFIRE AND ITS ROLE IN WILDFIRE OCCURRENCE-IS CRITICAL TO GUIDE RANGELAND MANAGEMENT IN THE FACE OF FIRE, FUELS, AND INVASIVE PLANTS. AT LARGE SPATIAL SCALES, EXISTING FUEL MODELING EFFORTS HAVE SHOWN THAT ANTECEDENT PRECIPITATION AMOUNT AND PATTERN CAN BE USED TO GENERALIZE WILDFIRE PROBABILITY. MISSING FROM THOSE EFFORTS HAS BEEN THE INCORPORATION OF BIOTIC STATUS (E.G., PLANT COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND FUNCTIONAL GROUP ABUNDANCE) INTO PREDICTIVE MODELS. INCORPORATING CURRENT BIOTIC INFORMATION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO DRAMATICALLY IMPROVE THE RELEVANCY OF EMPIRICALLY-DERIVED MODELS TO ON-THE-GROUND MANAGEMENT CONDITIONS AND DECISION MAKING. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS WORK ARE TO 1) EXAMINE THE BIOTIC DRIVERS OF AND RESPONSES TO WILDFIRE; AND 2) EXAMINE THE POTENTIAL FOR INCORPORATING BIOTIC COMPONENTS INTO ABIOTICALLY-DRIVEN (E.G., PRECIPITATION AT VARIOUS TIME LAGS) MODELS FOR PREDICTING WILDFIRE AND PLANT COMMUNITY RESPONSES. OBJECTIVES WILL APPLY ACROSS THE GREAT BASIN REGION.

DEVELOP A PROGRAM TO QUALIFY STUDENTS TO BECOME AGRICULTUAL STATISTICIANS. - THE OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP A SYSTEMATIC APPROACH FOR IDENTIFYING LOCI TO USE FOR METAGENOMIC STUDIES THAT WILL CHARACTERIZE DIFFERENT FORMAE SPECIALES OF FUSARIUM OXYSPORUM.

EASTERN OKLAHOMA COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT, INC AND NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL STATISTICS SERVICE - THE SUSTAINABLE SYSTEMS & COMMUNITIES PROGRAM (SSCP) AT THE NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL LIBRARY (NAL) IN BELTSVILLE, MARYLAND, WILL PROVIDE FARMERS IN MARYLAND, THE MID-ATLANTIC STATES, AND OTHER PARTS OF THE UNITED STATES, ACCESS TO AUTHORITATIVE INFORMATION ON SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS (INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO ORGANIC AND SUSTAINABLE FARMING, AQUACULTURE, ENERGY CROPS, AND EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE), AS WELL AS FARM CONSERVATION INFORMATION, INCLUDING INFORMATION ASSOCIATED WITH THE USDA CONSERVATION EFFECTS ASSESSMENT PROJECT (CEAP). THROUGH THE RESOURCES OF BOTH THE NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL LIBRARY AND UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EXTENSION, RESEARCHERS, GROWERS, AGRICULTURAL PROFESSIONALS AND OTHERS WILL HAVE ACCESS (VIA THE WEB, EMAIL, ONE-ON-ONE CONSULTATIONS, AND EXTENSION OUTREACH) TO AN EXTENSIVE KNOWLEDGE BASE OF CURRENT AND HISTORIC SUSTAINABLE FARMING SYSTEM AND CONSERVATION PRACTICES.THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON WHICH TO BASE SOUND FARMING DECISIONS THAT ARE ECONOMICALLY VIABLE, ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND, AND SOCIALLY ACCEPTABLE.

COLLECT, ANALYZE AND DISTRIBUTE STATISTICAL DATA FOR THE STATE-FEDERAL AGRICULTURAL STATISTICS PROGRAM IN THE STATE OF DELAWARE - GRAPEVINE COLD HARDINESS IS A COMPLEX TRAIT WHICH BEGINS IN FALL AS VINES ACCLIMATE AND CONCLUDES IN SPRING FOLLOWING BUDBURST. AS A RESULT, THE PHENOLOGICAL PROGRESSION DURING THE GROWING SEASON CAN IMPACT THE VINE'S PREPAREDNESS FOR WINTER. SIMILARLY, VERY COLD HARDY WILD GRAPEVINES CAN BURST VERY LATE IN THE SPRING, PREVENTING FROST DAMAGE. HOWEVER, THESE SAME VINES THEN DO NOT RIPEN AND ARE NOT READY FOR FALL. UNDERSTANDING THE GENETIC ARCHITECTURE OF PHENOLOGY IS THUS VERY IMPORTANT FOR COMBINING ESSENTIAL TRAITS IN NEW HYBRID GRAPEVINES.

Award Type: OTHER REIMBURSABLE, CONTINGENT, INTANGIBLE, OR INDIRECT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE
Description: DATA COLLECTION - SUPPLIES OF IRRIGATION WATER FOR LEAFY VEGETABLE PRODUCTION IN CALIFORNIA ARE INCREASINGLY CONSTRAINED DUE TO BOTH CLIMATE CHANGE AND REGULATORY RESTRICTIONS. REDUCED WATER AVAILABILITY IS A STATEWIDE PROBLEM AFFECTING ALL MAJOR LETTUCE PRODUCING REGIONS. A PREDICTED RISE IN TEMPERATURES WILL LEAD TO INCREASED EVAPOTRANSPIRATION THAT WILL INCREASE THE WATER REQUIREMENT OF LETTUCE. THUS, THERE IS A PRESSING NEED TO ADAPT LETTUCE PRODUCTION TO THE CHANGING ENVIRONMENT IN ORDER TO PROTECT AND EVEN INCREASE CURRENT PRODUCTION LEVELS. THE PURPOSES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO IDENTIFY TRAITS UNDERLYING DROUGHT-TOLERANCE IN LETTUCE AT BOTH THE PHYSIOLOGICAL AND MOLECULAR LEVELS AND INCORPORATE THESE TRAITS INTO NEW CULTIVARS PROTECTING YIELDS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO CONTRIBUTE TO WATER CONSERVATION, REDUCING PRODUCTION COSTS, AND INCREASING THE PROFITABILITY OF THE LETTUCE INDUSTRY WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY INCREASING THE SUSTAINABILITY AND PROTECTING THE FUTURE OF LETTUCE PRODUCTION IN CALIFORNIA.

2018 CENSUS OF AGRICULTURE HMONG DATA COLLECTION CBO PARTNERSHIP - SUPPLIES OF IRRIGATION WATER FOR LEAFY VEGETABLE PRODUCTION IN CALIFORNIA ARE INCREASINGLY CONSTRAINED DUE TO BOTH CLIMATE CHANGE AND REGULATORY RESTRICTIONS. REDUCED WATER AVAILABILITY IS A STATEWIDE PROBLEM AFFECTING ALL MAJOR LETTUCE PRODUCING REGIONS. A PREDICTED RISE IN TEMPERATURES WILL LEAD TO INCREASED EVAPOTRANSPIRATION THAT WILL INCREASE THE WATER REQUIREMENT OF LETTUCE. THUS, THERE IS A PRESSING NEED TO ADAPT LETTUCE PRODUCTION TO THE CHANGING ENVIRONMENT IN ORDER TO PROTECT AND EVEN INCREASE CURRENT PRODUCTION LEVELS. THE PURPOSES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO IDENTIFY TRAITS UNDERLYING DROUGHT-TOLERANCE IN LETTUCE AT BOTH THE PHYSIOLOGICAL AND MOLECULAR LEVELS AND INCORPORATE THESE TRAITS INTO NEW CULTIVARS PROTECTING YIELDS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO CONTRIBUTE TO WATER CONSERVATION, REDUCING PRODUCTION COSTS, AND INCREASING THE PROFITABILITY OF THE LETTUCE INDUSTRY WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY INCREASING THE SUSTAINABILITY AND PROTECTING THE FUTURE OF LETTUCE PRODUCTION IN CALIFORNIA.

CRASSIUSCULUS. THIS EXTENSION ALSO ALLOWS A SECOND YEAR OF FIELD WORK ON TESTING THE EFFICACY OF THESE CONTROL AGENTS IN NEW YORK AND IN TENNESSEE. 1) DETERMINE FOUNDRESS SURVIVAL AND BROOD PRODUCTION FOLLOWING EXPOSURE TO BOLTS TREATED WITH MYCOINSECTICIDES. 2) EVALUATE THE INTERACTION BETWEEN T. HARZIANUM AND THE BEETLE-SYMBIOTIC FUNGI AND DETERMINE IMPACT ON BROOD PRODUCTION. 3) COMPARE EFFICACY OF SPRAYING TREES WITH B. BASSIANA, M. BRUNNEUM OR T. HARZIANUM FOR AMBROSIA BEETLE CONTROL.

Award Type: OTHER REIMBURSABLE, CONTINGENT, INTANGIBLE, OR INDIRECT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE
Description: DATA COLLECTION - INFECTIONS WITH HERPES VIRUSES ARE KNOWN TO GENERATE POWERFUL CD8 T CELL RESPONSES AND THERE IS A LARGE BODY OF EVIDENCE INDICATING THAT THESE RESPONSES PLAY A KEY ROLE IN IMMUNITY TO THESE VIRUSES. THIS HAS PROMPTED RESEARCH TO EXPLORE THE POTENTIAL OF CERTAIN HERPES VIRUSES AS VACCINE VECTORS, FOCUSING PARTICULARLY ON DISEASES THAT REQUIRE CD8 T CELL RESPONSES FOR IMMUNITY. THE CAPACITY OF CD8 T CELLS TO ACT AS EFFECTORS AGAINST VIRAL INFECTIONS GENERALLY RELIES ON THEIR ABILITY TO RECOGNISE AND RESPOND TO VIRUS-INFECTED CELLS BEFORE THEY PRODUCE LARGE QUANTITIES OF VIRUS. IN THIS REGARD, CD8 T CELL RESPONSES TO HERPES VIRUSES SUCH AS HUMAN HERPES SIMPLEX VIRUS (HSV-1) TEND TO INCLUDE DOMINANT RESPONSES AGAINST THE IE PROTEINS AND IT IS THESE RESPONSES THAT ARE PREDOMINANTLY INVOLVED IN MEDIATING IMMUNE PROTECTION. IN ADDITION, A NUMBER OF HERPES VIRUSES HAVE A PREFERENTIAL TROPISM FOR MACROPHAGES AND DENDRITIC CELLS, THUS ENABLING THE INFECTED CELLS THEMSELVES TOACT AS ANTIGEN-PRESENTING CELLS FOR INDUCTION OF CD8 T CELL RESPONSES. ONE SUCH GROUP IS THE CYTOMEGALOVIRUSES (CMV), WHICH IN HUMANS CAUSE ASYMPTOMATIC INFECTIONS IN HEALTHY PEOPLE BUT CAN BE PATHOGENIC IN IMMUNOCOMPROMISED INDIVIDUALS. MOREOVER, SINCE CMVS ARE POOR INDUCERS OF NEUTRALISING ANTIBODIES, A CD8 T CELL RESPONSE CAN STILL BE INDUCED FOLLOWING IMMUNIZATION OF PREVIOUSLY INFECTED INDIVIDUALS. THE COMBINATION OF THESE PROPERTIES MAKES CMVS AN ATTRACTIVE PROSPECT FOR USE AS VACCINE VECTORS. RECENT STUDIES UTILISING SIMIAN CMV AS A VECTOR FOR DELIVERY OF SIMIAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRAL ANTIGENS HAVE SHOWN THAT IT INDUCES STRONG VIRUS-SPECIFIC CD8 T CELL RESPONSES AND HIGH LEVELS OF PROTECTION AGAINST VIRUS CHALLENGE. ALTHOUGH A CYTOMEGALOVIRUS HAS NOT BEEN IDENTIFIED IN CATTLE, BOVINE HERPES VIRUS 4 (BHV-4) SHARES A NUMBER OF PROPERTIES WITH CYTOMEGALOVIRUSES, WHICH HIGHLIGHT ITS POTENTIAL AS A VECTOR. ORIGINALLY CLASSIFIED AS A B-HERPES VIRUS AND REFERRED TO AS BOVINE CYTOMEGALOVIRUS, BASED ON ITS BIOLOGICAL PROPERTIES, BHV-4 WAS SUBSEQUENTLY FOUND TO BE A '-HERPES VIRUS. INFECTION WITH BHV-4 IS PREVALENT IN EUROPE AND USA AND ALTHOUGH THE VIRUS HAS BEEN ISOLATED FREQUENTLY FROM BOTH NORMAL AND DISEASED BOVINE TISSUES, THERE IS CURRENTLY NO EVIDENCE THAT IT IS THE CAUSATIVE AGENT OF DISEASE. LIKE CYTOMEGALOVIRUSES, BHV-4 IS REPORTED TO HAVE A PREDILECTION FOR THE MACROPHAGE LINEAGE AND IT INDUCES POOR NEUTRALIZING ANTIBODY RESPONSES. HENCE, IT IS LIKELY TO GENERATE CELLULAR IMMUNE RESPONSES IN PREVIOUSLY INFECTED ANIMALS AND COULD POTENTIALLY BE ADMINISTERED ON MORE THAN ONE OCCASION TO BOOST CELLULAR IMMUNE RESPONSES. BHV-4 HAS BEEN DEVELOPED AS A VACCINE VECTOR BY DR. GAITANO DONOFRIA, WHO HAS PRODUCED SEVERAL RECOMBINANT BHV-4 VIRUSES EXPRESSING VIRAL PROTEINS AND SHOWN THAT THEY STIMULATE STRONG ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN CALVES AND PROTECTION AGAINST THE RESPECTIVE VIRUSES. HOWEVER, THE ABILITY OF THE VIRUS TO INDUCE CELLULAR IMMUNE RESPONSES HAS NOT BEEN INVESTIGATED.

Award Type: OTHER REIMBURSABLE, CONTINGENT, INTANGIBLE, OR INDIRECT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE
Description: AGRICULTURAL INFORMATION COLLECTION, SUMMARIZATION, ANALYSIS AND DISSEMINATION - RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM DYSFUNCTION ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED WILDFIRE ACTIVITY, INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, AND EXPANDING CONIFERS IS NEGATIVELY IMPACTING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND A VARIETY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ACROSS THE WESTERN UNITED STATES. THESE FACTORS HAVE SEVERE ECONOMIC IMPLICATIONS; FOR EXAMPLE, FEDERAL FIRE SUPPRESSION EXPENDITURES IN FY 2017 APPROACHED $3 BILLION. THE INCREASING FREQUENCY OF WILDFIRES ACROSS WESTERN RANGELANDS REMAINS A THREAT TO ECOSYSTEM STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION. IN GREAT BASIN RANGELANDS, WILDFIRE OFTEN CREATES A POSITIVE FEEDBACK BY INCREASING INVASIVE ANNUALS AND ALTERING FUEL LOADING. UNDERSTANDING THE DYNAMICS OF THE PLANT COMMUNITY-BOTH IN RESPONSE TO WILDFIRE AND ITS ROLE IN WILDFIRE OCCURRENCE-IS CRITICAL TO GUIDE RANGELAND MANAGEMENT IN THE FACE OF FIRE, FUELS, AND INVASIVE PLANTS. AT LARGE SPATIAL SCALES, EXISTING FUEL MODELING EFFORTS HAVE SHOWN THAT ANTECEDENT PRECIPITATION AMOUNT AND PATTERN CAN BE USED TO GENERALIZE WILDFIRE PROBABILITY. MISSING FROM THOSE EFFORTS HAS BEEN THE INCORPORATION OF BIOTIC STATUS (E.G., PLANT COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND FUNCTIONAL GROUP ABUNDANCE) INTO PREDICTIVE MODELS. INCORPORATING CURRENT BIOTIC INFORMATION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO DRAMATICALLY IMPROVE THE RELEVANCY OF EMPIRICALLY-DERIVED MODELS TO ON-THE-GROUND MANAGEMENT CONDITIONS AND DECISION MAKING. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS WORK ARE TO 1) EXAMINE THE BIOTIC DRIVERS OF AND RESPONSES TO WILDFIRE; AND 2) EXAMINE THE POTENTIAL FOR INCORPORATING BIOTIC COMPONENTS INTO ABIOTICALLY-DRIVEN (E.G., PRECIPITATION AT VARIOUS TIME LAGS) MODELS FOR PREDICTING WILDFIRE AND PLANT COMMUNITY RESPONSES. OBJECTIVES WILL APPLY ACROSS THE GREAT BASIN REGION.
